awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Multi-Scale Calibrations of Fecal Biomarkers: New Tools to Evaluate How Herbivores Shaped Past Ecosystem Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Allison Karp has been granted an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research and education plans at Yale University and Brown University. Large-bodied mammalian herbivores are under threat, but it is unclear how these currently shifting communities may affect vegetation, fire and nutrient cycles. While these dynamics can be tested by examining how herbivores impacted ecosystem functions in the past, the tools available to reconstruct herbivore community changes alongside other environmental variables are limited. This research will fundamentally improve geochemical tools to analyze past herbivore dynamics by investigating herbivore biomarkers using samples from a National Park in South Africa with diverse wild herbivores. Dr. Karp will also develop educational and outreach materials for two parts of Yale’s Pathways to Science, which provides free scientific programing to middle and high-schoolers in New Haven as well as the greater public. 

This work will improve reconstructions of past herbivore dynamics from sediment cores with a comprehensive study to constrain if information about herbivore densities and community characteristics can be derived from fecal biomarkers produced from wild herbivore communities. To this end, Dr. Karp will conduct an integrated multi-scale calibration project in Kruger National Park (South Africa). The focus on African savannas, one of the few systems with a community of diverse megaherbivores, optimizes these calibrations to address questions related to shifts in extinct Quaternary herbivore communities. This research will: 1) test whether variation in fecal biomarker concentrations and distributions in dung is related to variation in herbivore functional groups, 2) examine fecal biomarker concentrations and microbial degradation in soils from decade-long herbivore exclusion experiment plots, and 3) calibrate sedimentary fecal biomarker characteristics to variation in the abundance and diversity of historical herbivore communities through time. This project combines the perspectives of modern and paleo-ecologists to produce paleoenvironmental insights grounded in modern settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Project Outcomes 

Large-bodied mammalian herbivores are critical to the functioning of terrestrial ecosystems, and their impacts are determined by both 1) overall herbivores abundance and 2) which herbivore species are in the community. Today, wild hebviore diversity and density is declining, while at the same time livestock densities are increasing. Studying how herbivores dynamics have changed in the past will allow us to better predict how current herbivore shifts will impact contemporary ecological processes. However, our ability to do this is limited by the tools available to reconstruct herbivore abundance and community changes though time. The aim of this grant was to fundamentally improve the fecal biomarker proxy for reconstructing past herbivore dynamics. Additionally, we used modern and paleoenvironmental data to test how herbivore, climate and fire dynamics interact in African savannas, which helps to frame the future questions that these new proxies can be used to address. 

Intellectual Merit 

We conducted a multi-scale calibration study in Kruger National Park (South Africa), a location with an intact and diverse community of wild herbivores. We collected herbivore dung samples and soils samples from decade-long herbivore exclusion experiments, then analyzed fecal biomarkers (i.e., organic compounds produced in the gut and excreted in herbivore dung) in these samples. Major findings from proxy calibration work included: 1) Concentrations of fecal biomarkers were significantly related to wild herbivore abundance on a landscape, 2) Ratios of particular compounds could be promising potential proxies for past herbivore abundance, and 3) Compound concentrations and distributions varied between species indicating that these compounds may preserve information about herbivore functional traits in wild communities.

Major findings from work examining relationships between rainfall, herbivory and fire activity included: 1) The magnitude of grazing effects on grass and fire activity was substantial across African savannas, and that while fire and herbivore densities are both dependent on rainfall gradients, grazing herbivores reduce fire activity consistently across those gradients in savannas. 2) Fire responses to rainfall shifts through time depend on whether fire activity is most limited by fuel amount (which increases with rainfall) or fuel moisture (which decreases with rainfall). Together, results indicate there are nuanced relationships between rainfall, herbivory and fire activity, and supports the use of new paleo-herbivore proxies developed in this grant to explicitly reconstruct how the impacts of changing herbivore densities may have changed fire regimes through time. 

Broader Impacts

1) Broadening participation in the STEM workforce by mentoring students from a variety of backgrounds. This project supported research experiences for three undergraduate students, and facilitated collaborations with scientists across multiple career stages including professors, research scientists, postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduate students. Of participants and core collaborators involved in this project, 45% were women and 62% were from other underrepresented groups. 2) Improved STEM education and public engagement though informal lectures to South African students about field work in Kruger National Park. 3) Results were disseminated to the public though 2 published papers to date in highly regarded disciplinary journals (Quaternary Science Reviews and Ecology Letters) with another 5 in advanced stages of preparation, two published senior theses, and 5 conference abstracts. 4) Professional development of PI Postdoc Karp, who mentored three students, learned new field and laboratory skills, and established new research directions that will span beyond the work of this grant. This fellowship opportunity contributed to a successful job search for a tenure-track position.
